title: Law banning deepfakes of candidates in place for first time in GE2025, among other guidelines: ELD
summary: This article covers Singapore’s new election laws and guidelines for GE2025, notably the first-time ban on deepfakes and digitally manipulated content misrepresenting candidates under the Elections (Integrity of Online Advertising) Act. Key legal points include strict controls on election advertising—both physical and online—with transparency requirements for paid ads and prohibitions on foreign involvement. The Films Act 1981 restricts political films, allowing only factual content. Election surveys and exit polls are banned from Writ issuance until Polling Day’s close. These measures aim to uphold election integrity, prevent misinformation, and ensure campaigns remain responsible and free from foreign interference, reinforcing Singapore’s commitment to fair democratic processes.

title: Intellectual property is the secret sauce for a flourishing music industry: Opinion
summary: This article explores the pivotal role of intellectual property (IP), particularly copyright, in safeguarding musicians' rights amid evolving technologies. It highlights key legal precedents such as the Ed Sheeran case, which reaffirmed that common musical elements like chord progressions are not copyrightable, and Taylor Swift’s battle over master recordings, emphasizing ownership and control issues in traditional record deals. The rise of AI-generated music introduces new complexities regarding originality and ownership. Singapore’s updated Copyright Act and collective management organisations provide robust protections, urging musicians to actively manage their rights through contracts, record-keeping, and legal advice. The takeaway: IP is essential for sustaining creativity and livelihoods in the music industry.

title: Generative AI a top priority for firms but privacy concerns remain: GIC survey
summary: This article discusses a GIC and Bain & Company survey highlighting generative AI as a strategic priority for firms, despite significant data privacy and talent concerns. Key legal aspects include data privacy compliance risks and the need for regulatory safeguards as companies adopt AI technologies. The survey reveals 36% of executives worry about privacy, underscoring the importance of robust data protection frameworks and due diligence. The article also touches on investment trends and the importance of identifying sustainable AI solutions amid hype, reflecting ongoing legal and regulatory scrutiny. The takeaway: firms must balance AI innovation with stringent privacy and compliance measures to mitigate legal risks.

title: New Law Academy programme will help young lawyers with ethical GenAI use, difficult clients
summary: The Singapore Academy of Law (SAL) launched the Junior Lawyers Professional Certification Programme to equip young lawyers with practical skills and ethical guidance on generative AI (GenAI) use and client management. Targeting lawyers with under five years’ experience, it addresses challenges like high attrition and limited training by accelerating legal insight and judgment development. Modules cover civil trials, cross-examination, legal tech, and difficult client handling. Chief Justice Menon highlighted attrition causes, urging sustainable workplace reforms. This initiative reflects a proactive response to AI’s disruption and evolving professional demands, aiming to better prepare junior lawyers for modern legal practice.

title: New training programme launched for young lawyers to stay ahead of AI curve, strengthen basic advocacy and drafting skills
summary: The Singapore Academy of Law (SAL) has launched the Junior Lawyers Professional Certification Programme (JLP) to equip young lawyers with AI literacy and reinforce core advocacy and drafting skills. Targeting lawyers within five years post-qualification, the voluntary programme offers structured modules on AI ethics, prompt engineering, and cross-border contracts, bridging the gap between Bar exams and specialist accreditation. It responds to the disruptive impact of generative AI tools like ChatGPT, raising client expectations and necessitating enhanced lawyer expertise. While addressing skill gaps and attrition, the JLP complements broader SAL initiatives tackling workplace pressures, with law firms pledging support for associate training.

title: Singapore’s alternative dispute resolution ecosystem must evolve to stay relevant: Murali
summary: This article discusses Singapore’s evolving alternative dispute resolution (ADR) ecosystem, emphasizing its role in providing legal certainty amid global volatility. Key legal points include Singapore’s commitment to international conventions like the New York Convention, Hague Choice of Court, and notably the Singapore Convention on Mediation, enhancing cross-border enforceability of dispute resolutions. Innovations such as AI-assisted mediation and liberalized dispute resolution regimes allowing international arbitrators reflect Singapore’s adaptive strategy. The article highlights emerging ADR trends like pre-commencement mediation and Singapore’s global prominence as a preferred arbitration seat. The takeaway: Singapore’s ADR framework is strategically positioned to meet dynamic international legal and commercial challenges efficiently.

title: GenAI in resume writing, job assessments: Fair use or foul play?
summary: This article explores the emerging legal and ethical considerations around the use of generative AI (GenAI) tools by job applicants during recruitment. Key legal aspects include employers’ varying policies on AI use—some banning it during assessments to ensure fair evaluation of candidates’ genuine skills, while others embrace AI as a legitimate aid reflecting modern workflows. The article highlights precedents of AI-friendly hiring practices with safeguards to detect misuse, balancing integrity and innovation. It underscores the evolving nature of employment law in AI contexts, emphasizing transparency, candidate honesty, and potential future policy adaptations. The takeaway: AI use in hiring remains a nuanced issue requiring careful regulatory and ethical navigation.

title: Woman who claimed ‘voices’ told her to abuse maid has jail term more than doubled to 7 years
summary: This article covers the High Court’s decision to more than double Anita Damu’s jail term for abusing her domestic worker, rejecting her defense of auditory hallucinations. Initially sentenced to 2 years 7 months based on psychiatric reports, the court found her claim of hearing voices fabricated after thorough assessment and testimony. Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon deemed the original sentence manifestly inadequate given the severity and cruelty of the abuse, increasing it to 7 years and raising compensation to $21,588. The case underscores judicial scrutiny of mental health defenses and reinforces accountability for domestic worker abuse in Singapore.

title: Fighting deepfakes with content ‘nutrition labels’: Opinion
summary: This article explores emerging legal and technological responses to the deepfake crisis, focusing on content "nutrition labels" that verify authenticity. Key legal developments include the EU’s AI Act (2024) and California’s Digital Content Provenance Standards Act (2026), both mandating disclosure of AI-generated or manipulated content. Adobe’s Content Credentials and Trust Mark tools embed metadata and invisible watermarks to prove content origin and edits, supporting transparency without targeting bad actors. However, adoption hurdles remain, such as limited browser support and inconsistent platform implementation. The initiative signals a shift toward global standards combating misinformation, empowering genuine creators and aiding legal compliance in digital content authenticity.

title: 3 out of 4 in Singapore cannot identify deepfake content: Cyber Security Agency survey
summary: This article highlights a 2024 Cyber Security Agency (CSA) survey revealing that 75% of Singaporeans struggle to identify deepfake videos despite high confidence levels. The rise of generative AI has complicated detection, increasing vulnerability to scams. The survey also notes mixed results in phishing awareness and an encouraging rise in cybersecurity practices like two-factor authentication and app installations. Experts warn that sophisticated AI-driven scams erode digital trust, threatening online service efficiency. CSA plans a national campaign to boost cyber hygiene. For legal professionals, this underscores evolving cyber risks, the importance of digital literacy, and potential regulatory or advisory roles in combating AI-enabled fraud.

title: CCCS takes action against car groomer Lambency Detailing for posting fake AI reviews
summary: The article discusses the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore’s (CCCS) action against Lambency Detailing for posting AI-generated fake five-star reviews on Sgcarmart.com. This marks the first CCCS case involving both a third-party platform and AI-created fake reviews, following a 2024 warning to Loft Home Furnishing for similar misconduct. Posting fake reviews is deemed an unfair trade practice as it misleads consumers. Lambency must remove the reviews, notify affected customers, and publish corrective notices. The case underscores regulatory vigilance over deceptive online reviews and highlights legal risks of using AI to manipulate consumer feedback.

title: At UN’s Wipo, Singaporean Daren Tang strives to create an equal music for haves and have-nots
summary: This article profiles Singaporean Daren Tang’s leadership of the UN’s World Intellectual Property Organization (Wipo), focusing on his efforts to democratize intellectual property (IP) beyond elite circles. Tang has emphasized simplifying IP, expanding access to innovators globally, and balancing protection of traditional knowledge with modern innovation, exemplified by treaties like GRATK and the Riyadh Design Law Treaty. He advocates for IP as a growth tool, not just legal rights, supporting creators from artisans to musicians. Tang also navigates emerging challenges like AI-generated works, underscoring Wipo’s facilitative role amid geopolitical complexities. His tenure highlights IP’s evolving role in equitable innovation and cultural preservation.

title: AI’s disruption of law firms could hold lessons for the broader business community: Opinion
summary: The piece warns that generative AI can displace routine junior lawyer tasks, forcing law firms to redesign workflows, retrain lawyers to critically vet AI outputs, and tighten risk controls (confidentiality, engagement terms, governance) to mitigate malpractice and supervision exposure; expect a ~20–30% reduction in entry roles but higher-value work and new roles (AI-knowledge managers). For Singapore, systemic change—education reform, AI-skilled professional services, and robust implementation guidance—is urgent if the jurisdiction aims to remain a competitive financial-legal hub amid rapid tech-driven disruption.

title: Prosecutors must be versatile to tackle challenges from AI-enabled crimes: Edwin Tong
summary: At the IAP conference, Law Minister Edwin Tong urged prosecutors to evolve legally and technically as generative AI lowers barriers to cross‑border crime—highlighting Interpol’s trillions‑dollar estimate, the McCartney child‑exploitation saga, and a regional takedown that seized AI‑made CSAM—to argue for multidisciplinary skills, updated prosecutorial powers over criminal-linked property, and stronger mutual legal assistance. Practically, this signals greater reliance on transnational cooperation, new MLAT frameworks (Singapore’s first Central Asian treaty with Kazakhstan), and evidence‑tech literacy for drafting charges, preserving digital evidence, and shaping policy to close enforcement gaps.

title: AI-powered search engine to help Singapore lawyers with legal research
summary: Singapore’s LawNet now hosts GPT-Legal Q&A, an SAL–IMDA AI search trained on Singapore judgments, SLRs, legislation and texts to answer natural-language legal queries (launch phased, starting with contract law), designed to limit hallucinations by only citing its source corpus and to complement—not replace—keyword search; practical effects include faster research, retention benefits, and a reminder that attorneys must still verify AI outputs. IMDA also demoed an agentic AI for corporate secretarial automation (timely after the Corporate Service Providers Act), and SAL struck distribution deals with LexisNexis, Thomson Reuters, vLex and Legora to boost global access and citation of Singapore cases.

title: S’pore still plugged into global conversations on AI, despite lack of consensus on oversight
summary: Singapore is keeping pace in global AI governance despite international disagreement—joining the UN’s new multistakeholder forum and independent 40‑member assessment panel—while exporting its playbooks via the Singapore Digital Gateway (AI Verify, Project Moonshot, National AI Strategy 2.0). Legally significant domestic moves include the forthcoming Online Safety (Relief and Accountability) Bill creating an Online Safety Commission with takedown powers and authority to disclose alleged perpetrators’ information, building on Singapore’s deepfake election ban; these developments signal enforceable national standards, cross‑border compliance challenges, and practical regulatory models for small states amid fractured multilateral oversight.

title: Lawyer ordered to pay client’s opponent $800 after discovery of fake case created by AI
summary: A Singapore assistant registrar fined a solicitor $800 after a junior’s AI-generated, non-existent case citation appeared in court papers, stressing the senior lawyer’s duty to supervise, verify authorities and not mislead the court; the conduct was deemed improper, unreasonable and negligent. The ruling cites the 2024 guide allowing generative AI but mandating independent verification, echoes warnings from Chief Justice Menon and Justice Aidan Xu, and signals practical consequences—personal costs orders, reputational harm and heightened supervisory and verification obligations when using AI in litigation.

title: AI in healthcare a game changer for Singapore, if we get the rules right first: Opinion
summary: Singapore’s piece warns that generative AI’s multi‑tasking capacity outstrips legacy medical-device regulatory frameworks, urging updates to the MOH/HSA AI in Healthcare Guidelines (AIHGle) and cross‑agency, international alignment; key legal issues are liability for AI‑generated misdiagnoses, informed consent and transparency about training data, explainability and bias, data‑provenance/privacy compliance, cyberattack risks, and evidentiary standards for real‑world validation. Regulators should treat AIHGle as a living rulebook, mandate rigorous post‑market surveillance/health‑technology assessment, and clarify clinician vs. vendor responsibilities to limit malpractice exposure while enabling beneficial deployment.

title: Breaches of AI policy could be a sackable offence at some Singapore law firms
summary: Following a High Court finding that counsel improperly cited a hallucinated case and was ordered to personally pay S$800, Singapore firms now treat GenAI breaches as serious disciplinary matters—ranging from restricted tool access to dismissal—emphasising that lead lawyers remain personally accountable for AI‑assisted work. The decision (Tajudin v Suriaya) is among the first local precedents penalising AI hallucinations, prompting firms to mandate verification, disclosure, training, two‑tier oversight and bespoke tool safeguards; its key legal lesson is that reliance on unverified AI outputs can incur professional and financial sanctions.

title: Use of Gen AI in legal practice must be balanced with careful oversight: Forum
summary: The Singapore Academy of Law urges firms to balance Gen AI efficiencies with clear oversight: adopt explicit internal policies (including sanctions), safeguard client confidentiality by vetting vendors, and train lawyers in prompt engineering and verification—recalling the recent hallucinated-case incident that underscores verification as a professional duty. SAL’s updated prompt guide and domain-specific legaltech (LawNet, LexisNexis, Thomson Reuters, vLex, Legora) offer safer research alternatives with curated databases and filters. Practically, firms should combine tool-specific controls, mandatory checks, and accountability mechanisms to preserve precision, integrity and regulatory compliance.

title: Law passed for scammers, mules, to be caned after victims in Singapore lose almost S$4b since 2020
summary: Parliament passed the Criminal Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (4 Nov 2025), imposing mandatory caning (6–24 strokes) for scammers and discretionary caning (up to 12) for facilitators like money mules, responding to about S$3.88bn losses since 2020; it also recalibrates caning for some offences. Key legal changes raise penalties for obscene-material and AI-generated sexual images, expand child-abuse definitions to realistic CGI, create a doxing-with-falsehood offence, toughen fatal abuse sentences (life now possible per a 2022 appeal rationale), broaden youth offender dispositions, and tighten precious-metals controls—raising deterrence and cross-border enforcement questions.

title: Two lawyers rapped over ‘entirely fictitious’ AI-generated citations submitted to court
summary: The High Court (Justice S Mohan) rebuked two lawyers for citing “entirely fictitious” cases—likely AI‑hallucinations—in closing submissions in a loan recovery matter, prompting inquiry into who used what tool and why. The ruling underscores counsel’s continuing duty to verify authorities and to disclose use of AI; sanctions are pending and follow an October decision ordering costs for similar conduct. Practically, firms should enforce AI policies, lawyers face professional discipline or personal costs, and courts will treat AI‑generated citations as a serious breach of citation and ethical obligations.

title: International commercial court networks can help spot cross-border legal trends, says Singapore chief justice
summary: Singapore Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon urged that transnational commercial court networks—exemplified by the new Bahrain International Commercial Court (BICC) with appeals to an International Committee of the Singapore International Commercial Court (SICC)—can uniquely identify cross‑border legal trends (contract interpretation, arbitration standards, crypto asset status, generative AI) and foster doctrinal convergence through reasoned judgments. The BICC/SICC model permits foreign counsel, foreign law and English proceedings, offers neutral adjudication for truly international disputes, and raises sovereignty questions mitigated by its limited, commerce‑focused remit.

title: ‘Deliberate subversion’ of P1 registration framework can lead to jail sentence: Judge
summary: This roundup signals a tightening Singapore legal landscape: courts and regulators are enforcing stricter corporate governance and fraud accountability (notable jail terms, directors’ penalties, and a set‑aside of a major arbitration award), expanding statutory remedies for online harms and data protection, and proposing harsher sanctions for scammers (including caning). Professional discipline is sharpening—lawyers face disbarment or costs for misconduct, including misuse of AI-generated authorities—while IP, employment, family and health‑info reforms show broad policy shifts toward tighter oversight, greater victim redress, and higher compliance risks for practitioners and clients.

title: Shady shades: Voyeurs and scammers can weaponise smart glasses – Commentary
summary: Smart glasses’ resurgence raises acute legal risks: covert recording, non‑consensual voyeurism, doxxing via live facial‑recognition and scraped data, deepfake creation, and distracted‑driver liability, yet statutes (e.g., voyeurism provisions) don’t neatly cover public or business settings. Expect businesses to adopt bans or policies (casinos as precedent), regulators to require tamper‑resistant recording indicators, and privacy/data‑protection claims and negligence suits where harms occur; criminal misuse could implicate stalking, fraud and image‑based abuse laws. Lawyers should watch emerging rules on device design, notice requirements, and civil remedies for reputational and privacy harms.

title: Singapore Courts: Cases of AI Fabrication a “Misuse of Technology”
summary: Singapore courts have made plain that lawyers remain personally liable for all court submissions and that AI‑generated “hallucinations” are a misuse of technology, reiterating the Guide on the Use of Generative AI Tools by Court Users: AI output must be independently verified, accurate and appropriate. Recent incidents—costs ordered against Lalwani for citing a fictitious authority and a pending decision involving counsel who filed non‑existent cases—underscore risks of negligence, potential personal cost orders, disciplinary referrals to the Law Society, and the need for strict verification and confidentiality safeguards when using AI.

title: Lawyers: AI is a supplementary tool and not a replacement for a lawyer’s judgement
summary: Recent fabricated‑case incidents show generative AI’s hallucination risk—especially in small firms with limited oversight—and underline that professional responsibility and verification remain paramount: lawyers must treat AI as a productivity aid, not a substitute for legal judgment, verify authorities cited, and disclose or obtain client consent where required. Large firms are responding with internal AI policies, training, supervised workflows, on‑prem tools and retrieval‑augmented systems to mitigate risks; expect continued emphasis on supervision, audit trails and possible Law Society/judicial guidance to codify disclosure, confidentiality and competency obligations.
